original_title: Sri Lanka to draft insolvency law
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s cabinet of ministers had approved drafting of an insolvency law to meet the needs of a modern economy within three months.
An Insolvency Ordinance had been issued in 1953 covering consumers and unincorporated businesses. There were also some provisions in the Companies Act of 2007.
But these provisions were considered insufficient to meet current needs.

President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Justice Minister Wijedasa Rajapaksa had proposed directing the Law Commission to discuss with relevant stakeholders and prepare an initial draft for an insolvency law within three months.
The cabinet had also approved drafting unspecified changes to the Banking Act of 1988.
The cabinet had also approved change to a Social Security Contribution Tax (Amendment) Bill. (Colombo/June27/2023)
